designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In late 2009, the Ministry of Finance and Economic Management (MFEM) of Vanuatu 
requested Asian Development Bank (ADB) technical assistance (TA) to develop and implement 
a state-owned enterprise (SOE) reform program. The government’s commitment to SOE reform 
is articulated in (i) Council of Minister's decisions 125 and 126/2009;1 (ii) its “Planning Long, 
Acting Short” matrix of policy priorities for 2009−2012; and (iii) its recent efforts to restructure 
two of the largest SOEs, the Vanuatu Commodities Marketing Board and Air Vanuatu. SOE 
reform is also an integral part of the approach to supporting private sector development in the 
ADB country partnership strategy 2010–2014 for Vanuatu.2  
 
2.  The April 2010 fact-finding mission resulted in a memorandum of understanding outlining 
the agreed impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, and terms of reference for 
the TA to support the government's SOE reform program. The TA will be provided concurrently 
with SOE reform measures already under way, including (i) the development of a restructuring 
plan for Air Vanuatu, which was initiated in May 2010 with Australian Agency for International 
Development support; (ii) the proposed repeal of the Vanuatu Commodities Marketing Board 
Act and amendment to the Public Finance and Economic Management Act, both of which were 
endorsed by Parliament in the second quarter of 2010; and (iii) the new Companies (Insolvency 
and Receivership) Bill, also expected to be considered by Parliament in the third quarter of 2010. 
The new Companies (Insolvency and Receiverships) Act, which was developed with ADB TA 
support, will provide a modern and country-specific regime for the dissolution of companies, 
including SOEs. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Vanuatu's SOEs absorb large amounts of scarce capital and provide very low returns, 
divert government resources away from vital social investments in health and education, and 
drive up the costs of doing business where they are the sole service providers. While poor 
financial  reporting  practices  mean  accurately  estimating  the  extent  of  the  fiscal  strain 
represented by the SOEs is difficult, a recent financial audit of one of the larger SOEs revealed 
that its accumulated losses totaled $20 million. Moreover, recent court rulings have affirmed that 
by virtue of the Public Finance and Economic Management Act 2006, the government can be 
considered a guarantor of the debts of SOEs. Vanuatu has 22 SOEs: 14 are engaged in 
commercial  activities,4 and  the  remaining  8  perform  various  noncommercial  functions  for 
government.5 Only 4 of the 14 commercial SOEs have  produced or reported  producing a 
commercial return in the past 5 years. 
 
                                                 
1  Desisen 125/2009: Review of Report on Copra Industry and Role of VCMB; Desisen 126/2009: State-Owned 
Enterprise Reform. 
2  ADB. 2009. Country Partnership Strategy: Vanuatu, 2010–2014. Manila. 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB's website on 3 June 2010. 
4  Of the 14 commercial entities, 9 are majority-owned by the central government, while the remaining 5 are minority 
shareholdings. 
5  National Tourism Office, Vanuatu Financial Services Commission, Reserve Bank of Vanuatu, Asset Management 
Unit, Utility Regulatory Authority, Vanuatu Telecommunications Regulator, Vanuatu Commodities Marketing Board, 
and Vanuatu Investment Promotion Authority.

2 
 
4.  The poor performance of the commercial SOEs can be attributed to two interrelated 
factors:  
 
(i)  Absence of a robust legal, governance, and monitoring framework. In the 
absence  of  a  robust  governance  framework  for  most  SOEs,  these  entities 
operate  without  performance  targets  or  accountability  for  results.  Director 
appointments are not made on the basis of professional qualifications; in the 
absence of performance contracts or statements of corporate intent, directors are 
not  held  accountable  for  their  performance  on  the  boards  or  for  SOE 
performance. In some cases, directors’ fees and expenses are often well above 
prudent  standards,  and  never  linked  to  outcomes,  further  distorting  any 
performance incentives.  
 
(ii)  Poorly  defined  mandates,  mixing  commercial  with  noncommercial 
activities. Compounding the weak governance frameworks is the absence of a 
clear mandate for many SOEs. Profit objectives are often mixed with directives to 
deliver community service obligations (CSOs), without due consideration to the 
financial  impact  of  the  CSOs  on  the  SOE.  This  distorts  the  performance 
incentives  of  the  SOE  and  complicates  the  decision-making  process  of  the 
boards. The existence of multiple shareholding ministries further complicates the 
operating environment and independence of the SOEs, as these ministries can 
and do originate CSO requests. To operate efficiently, commercial SOEs should 
have unambiguous profit objectives and a transparent mechanism to identify, 
contract,  and  finance  any  CSOs.  Without  this,  SOEs  cannot  set  and  meet 
performance targets, and the government cannot ensure that it is getting value 
for money for these CSOs or SOEs. 
 
5.  Previous government efforts to reform the SOE sector have had mixed results, largely 
due to the vested interests of the poorest performing SOE boards to maintain the status quo, 
where SOEs can operate without hard budget constraints, accountability, or consequences for 
poor  performance.  With  the  October  2009  Council  of  Minister's  decision,  a  larger  political 
consensus for reform has been achieved, providing the foundation for strengthening the legal 
and governance framework for the SOE sector. This step will be essential for establishing 
sustainable improvements in the sector’s financial performance. 
 
6.  The TA will support the development and implementation of an SOE reform program in 
Vanuatu to relieve the fiscal strain that SOEs place on the state budget and ensure that SOEs 
do not compromise consumer welfare or crowd out the private sector. To achieve this objective, 
action will be required to (i) strengthen the legal, governance, and monitoring framework for the 
SOE portfolio as a whole; and (ii) restructure the operations of selected priority SOEs.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The expected impact of the TA is reduced drain on the fiscal position of the government 
from  underperforming  public  enterprises.  This  will  be  measured  by  the  decrease  in  fiscal 
transfers to SOEs and reduction in the growth of contingent liabilities. 
 
8.  The TA outcomes will be improved financial, operating, and governance performance of 
SOEs. By the end of the TA, the legal, regulatory, and governance framework for SOEs will

3 
 
have been strengthened, at least four SOEs will have implemented rationalization measures, 
and the government will have agreed to a longer-term SOE reform pipeline, all of which will 
contribute to sustainability of the reforms. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA will build on the analytical work prepared under ADB's regional Private Sector 
Development Initiative,6 which produced a 2009 comparative study tracking the performance 
drivers of the SOEs in the Fiji Islands, Samoa, and Tonga.7 Vanuatu’s minister of finance and 
economic  management  endorsed  the  study's  recommendations  as  directly  applicable  to 
Vanuatu's SOEs, and stressed the importance of placing SOEs on a fully commercial footing. 
To achieve this goal, SOEs must have unambiguous commercial mandates, and the freedom 
and incentive to operate on commercial terms. Any and all regulatory activities must be carved 
out of their core commercial operations, and CSOs delivered within the commercial framework. 
The minister recognized that placing Vanuatu's SOEs on a commercial footing would require 
wholesale  reform  of  their  legal,  governance,  and  monitoring  frameworks,  in  parallel  with 
individual SOE restructuring efforts.  
 
10.  The TA will begin with strengthening the legal, governance, and monitoring frameworks 
for SOEs. This work will include (i) drafting an SOE act;8 (ii) establishing a robust process for the 
selection, appointment, and accountability of directors; (iii) strengthening the capacity of the 
SOE directors to execute their mandates; (iv) establishing a framework for contracting and 
financing CSOs; and (v) clarifying the role and responsibilities of the monitoring agency within 
MFEM.  The  recent  restructuring  of  MFEM  provides  an  opportunity  to  strengthen  its  SOE 
monitoring function, and this will be an integral component of the TA. 
 
11.  While the legal, governance, and monitoring reforms are being developed, a parallel 
effort to update SOE financial accounts will be undertaken, so that those that represent the 
greatest strain on the budget can be rapidly identified. The outputs of this work will also facilitate 
the development of necessary baseline indicators for assessing the performance of the TA. 
MFEM will lead this work, with support from the auditor general. Once MFEM identifies priority 
SOEs, at least 4 individual rationalization analyses will be undertaken, resulting in a set of 
recommendations  on  the  restructuring  of  SOE  operations  and  finances,  including 
recommendations on any regulatory reforms needed to support the rationalizations.9 
 
12.  Capacity-building efforts will be built into the TA to support the sustainability of the legal, 
governance, and monitoring reforms. At least six training courses on SOE governance and 
monitoring will be delivered for SOE directors and Ministry of Finance staff, and at least four 
director training courses will be offered for SOE directors. The success of the TA will be 
contingent on continued government support for implementation of the proposed reforms, and 
sufficient resources allocated to MFEM for their implementation.  
 
                                                 
6  ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance to the Pacific Region for Private Sector Development Initiative. Manila (TA 6353-
REG). 
7  ADB. 2009. Finding Balance: Making SOEs Work in Fiji, Samoa, and Tonga. Manila. 
8  The act will provide a legal framework for the operation, governance, and monitoring of SOEs. Restructuring of 
individual SOEs may also require amendments of their constituent acts, where these exist. Legal advice will be 
sought to ensure that legal issues are thoroughly considered and the government’s interests are protected in 
restructuring individual SOEs. 
9  These measures can include corporatization, restructuring, technology enhancements, public–private partnerships, 
privatization, and liquidation of the SOE or of selected SOE assets.

4 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $600,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on 
a grant basis through the provision of $500,000 by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, 
funded by the Government of Japan and administered by ADB. The Government of Vanuatu will 
provide $100,000 to finance office accommodation as well as accounting and auditing fees. 
Detailed cost estimates and the financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  ADB's  Pacific  Liaison  and  Coordination  Office  will  manage  the  TA,  and  coordinate 
directly with the Directorate of Finance within MFEM. The directorate has responsibility for SOE 
monitoring and is expected to serve as the secretariat to the Government Task Force on SOE 
Reform  chaired  by  the  minister  of  finance  and  economic  management,  as  per  Council  of 
Ministers Decision 126/2009. MFEM will be both the executing and implementing agency for the 
TA. The TA is expected to commence in October 2010 and be implemented over 23 months. 
 
15.  The Directorate of Finance will be responsible for developing the overall SOE reform 
strategy and implementation plan, which will include prioritization of SOE reforms. While the TA 
is expected to provide input into formulation of the SOE reform strategy, the focus of ADB’s 
technical support during the first phase will be the development of a new SOE act. This work will 
be conducted in close consultation with MFEM and key stakeholders, including the SOEs, line 
ministries, Prime Minister’s Office, State Law Office, and development partners. Subsequent 
phases of the TA will focus on developing individual SOE rationalization plans for the SOEs, as 
agreed jointly with the Directorate of Finance.  
 
16.  The  TA  team  will  comprise  technical  specialists  with  expertise  in  public–private 
partnership transaction structuring, institutional change, SOE reform, output-based aid, CSOs, 
and public financial management. If required, the TA team will be supported by legal specialists 
from  Vanuatu.  Detailed  terms  of  reference  for  the  consultants  will  be  developed  in  close 
coordination  with  ADB’s  Central  Operations  Services  Office.  Individual  consultants  will  be 
engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time). Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with the 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). A 
total of 16.5 person-months of international consultant time is expected to be required. Outline 
terms of reference for each output category of the TA are included in Appendix 3. 
 
17.  The Pacific Liaison and Coordination Office will monitor the TA. Good practices and 
lessons will be disseminated through training sessions and workshops, and through TA reports.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to the Government 
of Vanuatu to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for the 
State-Owned Enterprise Rationalization Program, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
1.  The required areas of expertise for international experts to be engaged for the technical 
assistance  (TA)  include  public–private  partnership  transaction  structuring;  institutional  change; 
state-owned enterprise (SOE) reform; output-based aid; community service obligations (CSOs), 
commercial law, SOE law, SOE monitoring, and public financial management. An outline of the 
broad terms of reference for each output category follows. More detailed terms of reference will be 
formulated for the recruitment of consultants.  
 
A.  Output 1: Preparation and Implementation of Rationalization Strategies 
2.  This  output  requires  engaging  international  consultants  for  11.5  person-months.  The 
preparation of rationalization strategies will involve identifying the government's stated objectives 
for SOEs, followed by a diagnostic assessment of each SOE's service delivery and financial 
performance  against  these  objectives.  The  diagnostic  will  include  a  review  of  legal,  taxation, 
regulatory, labor, technology, governance, and other relevant issues that affect performance. For 
SOEs  identified  for  divestment,  diagnostic  assessments  will  focus  on  the  market  impacts  of 
divestment to ensure that consumer welfare is not adversely affected.  
 
3.  Following  the  diagnostics,  sales  strategies  will  be  developed  for  SOEs  identified  for 
divestment,  and  rationalization  strategies  will  be  developed  for  SOEs  to  be  retained  under 
government ownership and whose performance will be enhanced. The rationalization strategies 
may entail financial or operational restructuring, technology enhancements, formalization of CSOs, 
contracting  out,  and  public–private  partnerships.  Once  the  government  agrees  with  each 
rationalization strategy, the consultants will actively support and participate in their implementation. 
 
4.  This output will require expertise in SOE reform, public–private partnership transaction 
structuring; contracting of CSOs, privatization transaction structuring, and corporate and financial 
restructuring. Specific sector expertise may be required depending on the sectors of activity of the 
selected SOEs, for example financial, banking, port management, shipping, and agroprocessing. 
Consultants  should  have  graduate  degrees  in  the  areas  of  focus  and  at  least  15  years  of 
professional experience in the selected sectors and areas of technical focus. Experience in the 
Pacific will be an advantage. 
 
B.  Output 2: Preparation of a Draft SOE Act 
5.  This output requires engaging international consultants for 2.5 person-months. To prepare 
the  new  SOE  act,  the  consultants  will  first conduct  a  review  of  (i)  the  legislative  and  policy 
framework for SOEs, (ii) the organization of their ownership and monitoring functions, (iii) the 
capacity  of  the  institutions  charged  with  the  monitoring  functions,  (iv)  the  adequacy  of  the 
accounting and financial reporting regime, and (v) the degree of management independence of the 
SOEs. This assessment should determine what actions, if any, are needed to improve the ability of 
the SOEs to operate as commercial entities as well as the ability of the government to monitor their 
performance and exercise its rights as shareholder. The consultants will then draft an SOE act and 
necessary amendments to associated legislation, for review and discussion with the Government 
and relevant stakeholders. The consultants will also organize stakeholder consultation sessions on 
the new law and support the introduction of the draft law to Parliament.  
 
6.  The output will require expertise in commercial law, SOE law, corporate governance, public 
financial management, the Vanuatu legal framework and legislative drafting. Once finalized, the

Appendix 3  9 
 
draft law will be translated into French, requiring input from a specialist translator. Consultants 
should have a law degree and hands-on experience developing and implementing SOE legislation, 
preferably in the Pacific region.  
 
C.  Output 3: Training courses on SOE Governance and Monitoring  
7.  This  output  requires  engaging  an  international  consultant  for  1  person-month.  The 
consultant will deliver training courses on the roles and responsibilities of directors (including the 
provisions of the new SOE law), SOE reporting and monitoring processes, board structure and 
appointment processes, the formation of audit committees and establishment of statements of 
corporate intent. It is anticipated that the consultants delivering this training will also be involved in 
outputs 2 above and 4 below. The consultant should have a graduate degree and at least 15 years 
of experience working with SOE governance issues. Experience in the Pacific will be an advantage. 
 
D.  Output 4: Development and implementation of a director performance evaluation 
system  
8.  This  output  requires  engaging  an  international  consultant  for  1.5  person-months.  The 
consultant will provide technical assistance to the SOEs and SOE monitoring units to develop a 
director performance evaluation system. The system will be anchored in the provisions of the new 
legal framework, and will reflect international best practice. It will be intended to strengthen the 
accountability mechanisms and duties and responsibilities of directors as outlined in the Company 
Law and new SOE act. The consultant will conduct a series of consultation sessions with SOE 
boards to develop the system, followed by implementation assistance to support the piloting of the 
new system.
